Name: Jean Bartik
Description: "For programming and co-leading the first teams of ENIAC programmers
Topics: and for pioneering work on BINAC and UNIVAC I."

Name: Jean Bartik
Topics: "For programming the ENIAC computer and helping adapt it to use software programs stored in memory."

Name: Alan J. Perlis
Description: For his influence in the area of advanced programming techniques and compiler construction.

Name: Maurice Wilkes
Description: Professor Wilkes is best known as the builder and designer of the EDSAC, the first computer with an internally stored program. Built in 1949, the EDSAC used a mercury delay line memory. He is also known as the author, with Wheeler and Gill, of a volume on Preparation of Programs for Electronic Digital Computers" in 1951
Topics: in which program libraries were effectively introduced."

Name: Richard Hamming
Description: For his work on numerical methods, automatic coding systems, and error-detecting and error-correcting codes.
Tags: Hamming code, Hamming window, Hamming numbers, Hamming distance

Name: Marvin Minsky
Description: For his central role in creating, shaping, promoting, and advancing the field of Artificial Intelligence.

Name: James H. Wilkinson
Description: For his research in numerical analysis to facilitiate the use of the high-speed digital computer, having received special recognition for his work in computations in linear algebra and backward" error analysis."

Name: John McCarthy
Description: Dr. McCarthy's lecture The Present State of Research on Artificial Intellegence" is a topic that covers the area in which he has achieved considerable recognition for his work."
Topics: Artificial intelligence, Programming languages, Programming paradigms

Name: Edsger W. Dijkstra
Description: For fundamental contributions to programming as a high, intellectual challenge; for eloquent insistence and practical demonstration that programs should be composed correctly, not just debugged into correctness; for illuminating perception of problems at the foundations of program design.
Topics: Foundations, Operating systems, Theoretical computer science, Algorithms & data structures, Concurrency, Programming languages, Programming paradigms
Tags: Dijkstra's algorithm, SPF, DJP algorithm, Semaphore, Mutex

Name: Charles Bachman
Description: For his outstanding contributions to database technology.

Name: Donald Knuth
Description: For his major contributions to the analysis of algorithms and the design of programming languages, and in particular for his contributions to the art of computer programming" through his well-known books in a continuous series by this title."
Topics: Algorithms & data structures, Theoretical computer science
Tags: TeX, KMP Algorithm, Knuth-Bendix Algorithm, LR grammar

Name: Allen Newell
Description: In joint scientific efforts extending over twenty years, initially in collaboration with J. C. Shaw at the RAND Corporation, and subsequentially with numerous faculty and student collegues at Carnegie-Mellon University, Newell and co-recipient #{Herbert A. Simon} made basic contributions to artificial intelligence, the psychology of human cognition, and list processing.
Tags: Logic theory machine, General problem solver, List processing

Name: Herbert A. Simon
Description: In joint scientific efforts extending over twenty years, initially in collaboration with J. C. Shaw at the RAND Corporation, and subsequentially with numerous faculty and student collegues at Carnegie-Mellon University, Simon and co-recipient #{Allen Newell} made basic contributions to artificial intelligence, the psychology of human cognition, and list processing.
Tags: List processing, Decision making, Logic theory machine, General problem solver

Name: Michael O. Rabin
Description: Along with #{Dana S. Scott}
Topics: for their joint paper "Finite Automata and Their Decision Problem
Tags: which introduced the idea of nondeterministic machines, which has proved to be an enormously valuable concept. Their (Scott & Rabin) classic paper has been a continuous source of inspiration for subsequent work in this field.,Theoretical computer science"
Source: Miller-Rabin primality test, Rabin-Karp algorithm, Nondeterministic finite automata, Randomized algorithms

Name: Dana S. Scott
Description: Along with #{Michael O. Rabin}, for their joint paper Finite Automata and Their Decision Problem
Topics: which introduced the idea of nondeterministic machines, which has proved to be an enormously valuable concept. Their (Scott & Rabin) classic paper has been a continuous source of inspiration for subsequent work in this field.
Source: Modal logic, Automata theory, Semantics of programming languages

Name: John Backus
Description: For profound, influential, and lasting contributions to the design of practical high-level programming systems, notably through his work on FORTRAN, and for seminal publication of formal procedures for the specification of programming languages.

Name: Robert W. Floyd
Description: For having a clear influence on methodologies for the creation of efficient and reliable software, and for helping to found the following important subfields of computer science: the theory of parsing, the semantics of programming languages, automatic program verification, automatic program synthesis, and analysis of algorithms.
Tags: Floyd-Wharshall Algorithm, Floyd–Steinberg Dithering, Floyd's cycle-finding algorithm

Name: Kenneth E. Iverson
Description: For his pioneering effort in programming languages and mathematical notation resulting in what the computing field now knows as APL, for his contributions to the implementation of interactive systems, to educational uses of APL, and to programming language theory and practice.

Name: C. A. R. Hoare
Description: For his fundamental contributions to the definition and design of programming languages.
Topics: Programming languages, Theoretical computer science, Concurrency, Operating systems

Name: Edgar F. Codd
Description: For his fundamental and continuing contributions to the theory and practice of database management systems.
Tags: OLAP, Relation model, Codd's cellular automaton, Codd's 12 rules, Boyce–Codd normal form

Name: Stephen Cook
Description: For his advancement of our understanding of the complexity of computation in a significant and profound way. His seminal paper, The Complexity of Theorem Proving Procedures
Topics: presented at the 1971 ACM SIGACT Symposium on the Theory of Computing, laid the foundations for the theory of NP-Completeness. The ensuing exploration of the boundaries and nature of NP-complete class of problems has been one of the most active and important research activities in computer science for the last decade.

Name: Ken Thompson
Description: With #{Dennis Ritchie}, for their development of generic operating systems theory and specifically for the implementation of the UNIX operating system.

Name: Dennis Ritchie
Description: With #{Ken Thompson}, for their development of generic operating systems theory and specifically for the implementation of the UNIX operating system.

Name: Niklaus Wirth
Description: For developing a sequence of innovative computer languages, EULER, ALGOL-W, MODULA and PASCAL. PASCAL has become pedagogically significant and has provided a foundation for future computer language, systems, and architectural research.

Name: Richard M. Karp
Description: For his continuing contributions to the theory of algorithms including the development of efficient algorithms for network flow and other combinatorial optimization problems, the identification of polynomial-time computability with the intuitive notion of algorithmic efficiency, and, most notably, contributions to the theory of NP-completeness. Karp introduced the now standard methodology for proving problems to be NP-complete which has led to the identification of many theoretical and practical problems as being computationally difficult.
Topics: Algorithms & data structures, Theoretical computer science
Tags: Edmonds–Karp algorithm, Karp's 21 NP-complete problems, Hopcroft–Karp algorithm, Karp–Lipton theorem, Rabin–Karp algorithm

Name: John Hopcroft
Description: With #{Robert Tarjan}, for fundamental achievements in the design and analysis of algorithms and data structures.
Topics: Algorithms & data structures, Theoretical computer science

Name: Robert Tarjan
Description: With #{John Hopcroft}, for fundamental achievements in the design and analysis of algorithms and data structures.
Topics: Algorithms & data structures, Theoretical computer science

Name: John Cocke
Description: For significant contributions in the design and theory of compilers, the architecture of large systems and the development of reduced instruction set computers (RISC); for discovering and systematizing many fundamental transformations now used in optimizing compilers including reduction of operator strength, elimination of common subexpressions, register allocation, constant propagation, and dead code elimination.

Name: Ivan Sutherland
Description: For his pioneering and visionary contributions to computer graphics, starting with Sketchpad, and continuing after.

Name: William Kahan
Description: For his fundamental contributions to numerical analysis. One of the foremost experts on floating-point computations. Kahan has dedicated himself to making the world safe for numerical computations

Name: Fernando J. Corbató
Description: For his pioneering work organizing the concepts and leading the development of the general-purpose, large-scale, time-sharing and resource-sharing computer systems, CTSS and Multics.

Name: Robin Milner
Description: For three distinct and complete achievements: LCF, the mechanization of Scott's Logic of Computable Functions, probably the first theoretically based yet practical tool for machine assisted proof construction; ML, the first language to include polymorphic type inference together with a type-safe exception-handling mechanism; and CCS, a general theory of concurrency. In addition, he formulated and strongly advanced full abstraction, the study of the relationship between operational and denotational semantics.
Tags: LCF, ML, Calculus of communicating systems, Pi-calculus, Hindley-Milner type inference

Name: Butler W. Lampson
Description: For contributions to the development of distributed, personal computing environments and the technology for their implementation: workstations, networks, operating systems, programming systems, displays, security and document publishing.

Name: Juris Hartmanis
Description: With #{Richard E. Stearns}, in recognition of their seminal paper which established the foundations for the field of computational complexity theory.

Name: Richard E. Stearns
Description: With #{Juris Hartmanis}, in recognition of their seminal paper which established the foundations for the field of computational complexity theory.

Name: Edward Feigenbaum
Description: For pioneering the design and construction of large scale artificial intelligence systems, demonstrating the practical importance and potential commercial impact of artificial intelligence technology.

Name: Raj Reddy
Description: For pioneering the design and construction of large scale artificial intelligence systems, demonstrating the practical importance and potential commercial impact of artificial intelligence technology.

Name: Manuel Blum
Description: In recognition of his contributions to the foundations of computational complexity theory and its application to cryptography and program checking.
Tags: Blum complexity axioms, Blum's speedup theorem, Blum Blum Shub, Blum-Goldwasser cryptosystem

Name: Amir Pnueli
Description: For seminal work introducing temporal logic into computing science and for outstanding contributions to program and system verification.

Name: Douglas Engelbart
Description: For an inspiring vision of the future of interactive computing and the invention of key technologies to help realize this vision.

Name: Jim Gray
Description: For seminal contributions to database and transaction processing research and technical leadership in system implementation.
Tags: Five minute rule, Granular database locking

Name: Frederick P. Brooks
Description: For landmark contributions to computer architecture, operating systems, and software engineering.

Name: Andrew Chi-Chih Yao
Description: In recognition of his fundamental contributions to the theory of computation, including the complexity-based theory of pseudorandom number generation, cryptography, and communication complexity.

Name: Ole-Johan Dahl
Description: With #{Kristen Nygaard}, for ideas fundamental to the emergence of object oriented programming, through their design of the programming languages Simula I and Simula 67.

Name: Kristen Nygaard
Description: With #{Ole-Johan Dahl}, for ideas fundamental to the emergence of object oriented programming, through their design of the programming languages Simula I and Simula 67.

Name: Ronald L. Rivest
Description: Together with #{Leonard Adleman} and #{Adi Shamir}, for their ingenious contribution to making public-key cryptography useful in practice.
Tags: Public-key, RSA, RC2, RC4, RC5, RC6, MD2, MD4, MD5, MD6, Ring signature

Name: Adi Shamir
Description: Together with #{Leonard Adleman} and #{Ronald L. Rivest}, for their ingenious contribution to making public-key cryptography useful in practice.

Name: Leonard Adleman
Description: Together with #{Ronald L. Rivest} and #{Adi Shamir}, for their ingenious contribution to making public-key cryptography useful in practice.

Name: Alan Kay
Description: For pioneering many of the ideas at the root of contemporary object-oriented programming languages, leading the team that developed Smalltalk, and for fundamental contributions to personal computing.

Name: Vint Cerf
Description: With #{Bob Kahn}, for pioneering work on internetworking, including the design and implementation of the Internet's basic communications protocols, TCP/IP, and for inspired leadership in networking.

Name: Bob Kahn
Description: With #{Vint Cerf}, for pioneering work on internetworking, including the design and implementation of the Internet's basic communications protocols, TCP/IP, and for inspired leadership in networking.

Name: Peter Naur
Description: For fundamental contributions to programming language design and the definition of Algol 60, to compiler design, and to the art and practice of computer programming.

Name: Frances E. Allen
Description: For pioneering contributions to the theory and practice of optimizing compiler techniques that laid the foundation for modern optimizing compilers and automatic parallel execution.

Name: E. Allen Emerson
Description: Together with #{Edmund M. Clarke} and #{Joseph Sifakis}, for their role in developing Model-Checking into a highly effective verification technology that is widely adopted in the hardware and software industries.

Name: Edmund M. Clarke
Description: Together with #{E. Allen Emerson} and #{Joseph Sifakis}, for their role in developing Model-Checking into a highly effective verification technology that is widely adopted in the hardware and software industries.

Name: Joseph Sifakis
Description: Together with #{Edmund M. Clarke} and #{E. Allen Emerson}, for their role in developing Model-Checking into a highly effective verification technology that is widely adopted in the hardware and software industries.

Name: Barbara Liskov
Description: For contributions to practical and theoretical foundations of programming language and system design, especially related to data abstraction, fault tolerance, and distributed computing.
Tags: Venus, CLU, Argus, Thor, Liskov substitution principle

Name: Charles P. Thacker
Description: For the pioneering design and realization of the first modern personal computer -- the Alto at Xerox PARC -- and seminal inventions and contributions to local area networks (including the Ethernet), multiprocessor workstations, snooping cache coherence protocols, and tablet personal computers.

Name: Leslie G. Valiant
Description: For transformative contributions to the theory of computation, including the theory of probably approximately correct (PAC) learning, the complexity of enumeration and of algebraic computation, and the theory of parallel and distributed computing.

Name: Judea Pearl
Description: For fundamental contributions to artificial intelligence through the development of a calculus for probabilistic and causal reasoning.

Name: Silvio Micali
Description: Along with #{Shafi Goldwasser}, for transformative work that laid the complexity-theoretic foundations for the science of cryptography, and in the process pioneered new methods for efficient verification of mathematical proofs in complexity theory.
Tags: Goldwasser–Micali cryptosystem, Zero-knowledge proof, Pseudorandom Functions

Name: Shafi Goldwasser
Description: Along with #{Silvio Micali}, for transformative work that laid the complexity-theoretic foundations for the science of cryptography, and in the process pioneered new methods for efficient verification of mathematical proofs in complexity theory.

Name: Leslie Lamport
Description: For fundamental contributions to the theory and practice of distributed and concurrent systems, notably the invention of concepts such as causality and logical clocks, safety and liveness, replicated state machines, and sequential consistency.

Name: Michael Stonebraker
Description: For fundamental contributions to the concepts and practices underlying modern database systems.

Name: Martin E. Hellman
Description: Along with #{Whitfield Diffie}, for critical contributions to modern cryptography.

Name: Whitfield Diffie
Description: Along with #{Martin E. Hellman}, for critical contributions to modern cryptography.
